intro: Gagea amblyopetala var. pumila, commonly known as the dwarf gagea, is a perennial bulbous plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its small, grass-like leaves and clusters of bell-shaped, white or pale pink flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, well-drained soils in woodland or open areas. It is known for its early spring blooming habit and is often found in mountainous regions. The variety pumila is distinguished by its shorter stature compared to other varieties of Gagea amblyopetala.
